Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Improved Computational Tools for Plant Gene Assembly and Synteny Detection
Award.AbstractNarration:
The ever-increasing rate of genome sequence production will result in literally thousands of genome sequences being determined. Current automated methods for plant gene assembly have certain inherent weaknesses that result in many incorrectly assembled genes due to inaccurate detection of true intron-exon boundaries including GC boundaries, inability to detect N-terminal exons, and inappropriate fusion of adjacent genes. Expert manual annotation can usually overcome these limitations, but manual annotation is not scalable to many thousands of genes. Genome projects generally are able to claim only 1000-3000 genes were manually checked. In plant genomes this may be only 3-10% of the genes in the genome. This EAGER project seeks to improve automated plant gene assembly and annotation with a focus on cytochrome P450 genes, which comprise one of the largest gene families in plants. Successful implementation of accurate gene prediction algorithms and the development of a novel tool for identifying ohnologs (genes created by whole genome duplication events) in plant genomes will have a transformative effect on genome annotation.

This project will provide international cross-disciplinary training opportunities for one postdoctoral research associate. All programs will be available as a set of executable files from an ftp site and through the project website, both of which will be accessible via http://www.uthsc.edu/molecular_sciences/directories/faculty/d_nelson.php. The source code will also be made available at this location.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The motivation behind this project was to make an algorithm that would be able to quickly and accurately assemble genes from plant genomes (i.e. find the beginning and end of the gene as well as all intron-exon boundaries to assemble a correct protein translation of the gene). Automated methods in use were flawed and insufficiently accurate, leading to many incorrect gene models that are deposited in widely used sequence databases such as Genbank, DDBJ and EMBL. Common errors involved the fusion of adjacent genes, the skipping of exons creating short protein models, failure to detect correct beginnings of proteins, and misassembly of pseudogenes inappropriately into predicted complete proteins. Our method uses representative seed sequences that have been manually evaluated as accurate. These are aligned into a multiple sequence alignment to be used as a guide in building gene models from the genomic DNA. Error checking would therefore detect skipped exons (causing a gap in the alignment to the seed sequences), retained introns (causing an insertion in the alignment), missed ends leading to overly short ends. Furthermore, pseudogenes could be detected as having stop codons in inappropriate places, or shifts in translated reading frames that broke the sequence alignment. We were successful in creating this algorithm composed of several modules as described in our 2014 publication:

 

Osamu Gotoh, Mariko Morita and David R. Nelson (2014) Assessment and refinement of eukaryotic gene structure prediction with gene-structure-aware multiple protein sequence alignment. BMC Bioinformatics 2014 Jun 14;15(1):189.

 

The software significantly outperforms other available methods tested as demonstrated by benchmark comparisons in this paper. The software is available for download from

 

http://www.genome.ist.i.kyoto-u.ac.jp/~aln_user/

 

This method relies on the availability of close homologs (proteins with similar amino acid sequences) collected from public databases and by manual curation of genomic data. Once these are collected and checked for accuracy the multiple sequence alignment made from these sequences then provides the needed information to accurately assemble a gene from genomic DNA. The method was developed using cytochrome P450 sequences (many of them manually assembled and named by DRN). To show the generality of the method ribosomal proteins were used to confirm the method works with other protein families, and is therefore applicable to any protein family. Manual detection and assembly is a slow tedious process that can take weeks to months for even a single genome. One of the earliest plant genomes [the Western black cottonwood (Populus trichocarpa)] analyzed for cytochrome P450 genes took about 4.5 months of work to assemble several hundred genes, working with a series of improved genome assemblies. To demonstrate the power of the new algorithm 60 plant genomes were downloaded from public sources and processed to find and assemble 17,610 cytochrome P450 genes. These genes are from valuable crop plants (rice, maize, soybeans, cotton, tomato, potato, cocoa, tea, peaches, strawberries, bananas, date palm) and evolutionarily relevant plants like Amborella, the earliest diverging flowering plant. The number of P450s in this set is more than twice the number of named plant P450s documented at the Cytochrome P450 Homepage over the past 19 years. This represents a significant advance in automated plant gene assembly, but it should also be applicable to any other eukaryotic organisms with intron containing genes. Another example is fungal genomes. The algorithm was able to find 2122 P450 genes in 18 fungal genomes from the fungal class Dothideomycetes. These fungal gene sequences have since been named.
